question: Question_02
statement:
Let $\mathbb{P}_3$ be the vector space of polynomials of degree
$\leq 3$. The monomials $1,x, x^2, x^3$ form a basis of $\mathbb{P}_3$.
Consider the linear mapping from $\mathbb{P}_3$ into $\mathbb{P}_3$
given by $p(x) \mapsto p''(x)$. Find the matrix A of the mapping with
respect to the monomial basis and determine its null space.
sols:
The number of basis vectors equals the dimension of the vector space, so
$\mathbb P_3$ has dimension 4. To begin with, we represent the basis
monomials as vectors:

\begin{align*}
1 \leftrightarrow e_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad x \leftrightarrow e_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad x^2 \leftrightarrow e_3 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad x^3 \leftrightarrow e_4 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

Then, a general polynomial $\displaystyle a_3x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_1x + a_0$
can represented as

\[a_3x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_1x + a_0 = a_3e_4 + a_2e_3 + a_1e_2 + a_0e_1 = \begin{bmatrix} a_0 \\ a_1 \\ a_2 \\ a_3 \end{bmatrix}\]

in the given basis. Next we calculate how \emph{A} acts on the basis:

\begin{align*}
Ae_1 &= 1'' = 0 \\
Ae_2 &= x'' = 0 \\
Ae_3 &= (x^2)'' = 2 = 2e_1 \\
Ae_4 &= (x^3)'' = 6x = 6e_2
\end{align*}

This determines the columns of \emph{A}, i.e.

\[A = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & 2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 6 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{bmatrix}\]

To double check this we calculate

\begin{align*}
(a_3x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_1x + a_0)'' &\leftrightarrow A\begin{bmatrix} a_0 \\ a_1 \\ a_2 \\ a_3 \end{bmatrix} \\
6a_3x + 2a_2 &\leftrightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 2a_2 \\ 6a_3 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \\
6a_3e_2 + 2a_2e_1 &\leftrightarrow 6a_3 \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + 2a_2\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \quad \checkmark
\end{align*}

Finally, since the second derivative of the first two monomials is zero,
the two corresponding vectors form a basis of the null space of
\emph{A}:

$N(A)=\text{span} \left( \left\{ \begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
0\\ 
0\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
1\\ 
0\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix} \right\} \right)$
hints:
What is the dimension of $\mathbb{P}_3$? How can you represent a general
polynomial of $\mathbb{P}_3$ in vector notation, that is, as a linear
combination of the given basis?

How does \emph{A} act on the basis vectors? In other words, calculate
the second derivative of the basis vectors and write your results in
vector notation.

To find the null space look at the zero columns of \emph{A}. To check
your answer, which of the basis monomials get mapped to the zero
polynomial when you take the second derivative?
